answers.answer: Hey Erin,I know that medications can cause dry mouth, my son gets dry on his anxiety meds, not sure about my daughters meds though she complains of nausia, vomiting and bowel pain alot and sticks to the foods that she can tollerate. Oh she does say she often feels like she has something stuck in her throat but i cant recall her saying dry.Could one of your meds be causing this if its new?Cheers......JJ

Is started Vesicare for bladder issues and with it came the extreme dry mouth.  I stopped because I couldn't even speak.The med was working wonderfully and I am going to try again.  My neuro said that drinking a lot of water will wash the saliva out of your mouth and make the dry mouth worse.  He said that there are over the counter remedies to help the issue and I plan on stopping at my local Walgreens and asking about them.If you feel as though it is more of a thirst issue, I would see your regular Dr. to see what is going on.  Diabetes can cause that symptom.  As for MS causing it, I don't know.  It seems to cause just about every symptom we can possibly imagine!  Try your regular, non-MS Dr. first.  You seem to have some issues going on that need to be looked at.

I get dry mouth from my bladder meds, but I'm thinking you ought to have your sugar levels checked for diabetes.  My friend recently had your exact symptoms and found she was definitely diabetic.Hope you find the answer soon!

Everyone has told you what  I would have said - I don't think it is MS symptom, but may be a byproduct of the meds your are taking.Be sure to discuss the diabetes question, because that can cause this dry mouth too.I know what everyone means by the parched, can't talk dryness that hits.  I get that regularly from my bladder drug, but it seems to be getting better. The literature on it says that will improve with time.I could drink gallons of water too, but my neuro and my urologist have put me on a drinking plan, trying to curb the urgency and the nocturia.  It has worked, but I am really thirsty!I keep hard candies (peppermints) and sugar free gum handy.  One of those always helps to get my saliva flowing again.as always,Lulu
